itemDescription: British broadcasting executive and anti-racist campaigner (1929-2020)

wikipedia_page.main: Dame Jocelyn Anita Barrow  (15 April 1929 – 9 April 2020) was a British educator, community activist and politician, who was the Director for UK Development at Focus Consultancy Ltd. She was the first black woman to be a governor of the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) and was founder and Deputy Chair of the Broadcasting Standards Council.

response: * Jocelyn Barrow, British educator, community activist and politician

link_mentions.page: List of Dames Commander of the Order of the British Empire
response: *1992: Jocelyn Barrow, Ann Ebsworth, Rangimarie Hetet, Edna Lewis, Moura Lympany, Wendy Mitchell, Shirley Oxenbury, Anne Poole, Norma Restieaux, Angela Rumbold, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, The Baroness Serota, Janet Smith

The Townswomen's Guilds' (TG) Patron is Her Royal Highness The Princess Royal, and the organisation's National President is Dame Diana Brittan DBE. Its National Vice-Presidents are Dame Jocelyn Barrow DBE, Eileen Bell CBE and Baroness Flather.

CARD's founding members included Jocelyn Barrow as well as Marion Glean, politician Anthony Lester, London County Councillor David Pitt, historian C. L. R. James, Dipak Nandy and the sociologist Hamza Alavi.Kalbir Shukra, The Changing Pattern of Black Politics in Britain, London: Pluto Press, 1998,  (p. 20). Lawyer Richard Small served as CARD's press officer.

link_mentions.page: List of name changes due to the George Floyd protests
response: | Residents and businesses on the street have been asked to choose a new name from a shortlist of two: Jocelyn Barrow Lane and La Rose Lane, after John La Rose.

link_mentions.page: Mayor's Commission on African and Asian Heritage
response: Mayor's Commission on African and Asian Heritage (also known as MCAAH) was established by Ken Livingstone when he was Mayor of London. MCAAH was convened from August 2003 to June 2004 and was chaired by Dame Jocelyn Barrow. More than 20 practitioners, policy-makers and academics were appointed as commissioners and met around a programme of 15 sessions across London. The MCAAH's report, Delivering Shared Heritage (July 2005), was launched at the Victoria and Albert Museum.
